description: From Middle English blacche (“black pigment or dye; black colour; black individual”), from Old English blæċċe (“black matter”), from Proto-West Germanic *blakkjā (“that which is black; blackness”), from Proto-Germanic *blakjǭ, from Proto-Germanic *blakaz (“black”).
From Middle English blacchen, from the noun above.

verbs.description: blatch (third-person singular simple present blatches, present participle blatching, simple past and past participle blatched)

entries.meaning: (transitive, archaic) To blacken; to smear with blacking; to stain or mark with soot or coal.
